docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Subdivision 1 General jurisdiction in relation to actions [ss 44–48]

heading.title: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]
Subdivision 1 General jurisdiction in relation to actions [ss 44–48]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]
Subdivision 1 General jurisdiction in relation to actions [ss 44–48]

leg:heading.title: General jurisdiction in relation to actions* [ss 44–48]

p.text: Subject to this Act, the Court has jurisdiction to hear and dispose of the following actions:
any action of a kind:
which, if brought in the Supreme Court, would be assigned to the Common Law Division of that Court, and
in which the amount (if any) claimed does not exceed the Court's jurisdictional limit, whether on a balance of account or after an admitted set-off or otherwise,
other than an action referred to in paragraph (d) or (e),
[repealed]

any action brought to recover an amount not exceeding $20,000, which is the whole or part of the unliquidated balance of a partnership account, or the amount or part of the amount of the distributive share under an intestacy or of a legacy under a will.
any motor accident claim, irrespective of the amount claimed.
any work injury damages claim, irrespective of the amount claimed,
any proceedings transferred to the Court under section 146(1) of the Civil Procedure Act 2005, irrespective of the amount (if any) claimed in those proceedings.

[subs (1) subst Act 12 of 1991 s 3 and Sch 2(1) ; am Act 58 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 141 of 1997 s 2 and Sch 1 ; Act 94 of 2001 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 January 2002 ; Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005; Act 56 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 5[4], effective 14 December 2007]

Where the amount claimed in an action includes interest (being interest which the Court could, under section 100(1) of the Civil Procedure Act 2005, order to be included in the amount for which it could give judgment), that interest shall be disregarded for the purposes of—
determining whether the maximum amount for which the action is authorised by this Act to be brought has been exceed or not; and
determining whether or not the Court has jurisdiction to hear and dispose of the action.
[subs (2) subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 3 ; am Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]
Where—

an amendment to 2 subsection (1) which is enacted after, or was enacted before the commencement of Schedule 3 to the District Court (Procedure) Amendment Act, 1984, has or had the effect of increasing the amount specified in paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection; and

an action in which an amount of money is claimed is pending at the time when the amendment has effect or, as the case may be, an action in which an amount of money is claimed was pending at the time when the amendment had effect and has not been finally determined,

the Court may, on the application of the claimant, make an order altering the amount specified in the claim to an amount not exceeding that specified in paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection, as in force immediately after the amendment has or had effect.
[subs (3) subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 3 ; am Act 12 of 1991 s 3 and Sch 2(1)]

The rules of court are taken to include the UCP Rules to the extent to which they are applicable in the District Court: s 10(1) of the CP Act. The UCP Rules prevail over any provision of the rules made under the District Court Act, to the extent of any inconsistency and subject to any express contrary provision contained in rule 1.7 and Schedule 2 of the UCP Rules: s 11 of the CP Act. The contrary provisions contained in Schedule 2 relate to Pt 24D (Coal Miners Workers Compensation List) Rules 15, 17, 18, 20 and 30; Pt 24F (Special Statutory Compensation List) Rule 4 and Pt 39B (Costs in Coal Miners’ Workers Compensation List and Special Statutory Compensation List matters) — all rules in that Part. However, nothing in the UCP Rules extends the jurisdiction of the District Court except to the extent to which the CP Act expressly so provides: s 5(2) of the CP Act. Section 44 was amended by the Courts Legislation Further Amendment Act 1997, effective 2 February 1998. The amendment gave the court unlimited jurisdiction in motor accident claims, as well as unlimited jurisdiction in any proceedings transferred from the Supreme Court under s 143 of the District Court Act 1973 (as it then was). Those amended provisions applied to proceedings for which an order for transfer from the Supreme Court was made before 2 February 1998: Cremona v Shon [1998] NSWSC 390; BC9804078 . Section 146 of the CP Act enables orders to be made for transfer of proceedings from the Supreme Court to the District Court and in relation to personal injury or death claims there is a direction that such proceedings are to be transferred unless the Supreme Court is satisfied of certain matters: s 146(4) of the CP Act. The District Court has, and may exercise, all of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in relation to any proceedings to which a transfer order relates, including jurisdiction to determine any question arising in any such proceedings: s 149 of the CP Act.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 44.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 4, s 44, s 44(1)(a), s 44(1)(d)-(e).
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCA s 53(4).

The District Court’s general “jurisdictional limit” is defined in DCA s 4 at $750,000. That limit applies, in the absence of any contrary indication (such as that contained in DCA s 44(1)(d)-(e) ) to any proceedings that would fall within the business assigned to the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court. However, that jurisdictional limit does not prevent the court from giving judgment for an amount in excess of the limit. It only prevents the successful party from recovering more than the limit, exclusive of costs and interest: Richards v Cornford [2010] NSWCA 99; BC201002878 at [12] .

Section 44 was amended to its present form by the Courts Legislation Further Amendment Act 1997 (NSW) commencing on 2 February 1998. The jurisdiction given is by reference to actions which if brought in the Supreme Court would have been assigned to the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court as at 2 February 1998. In this respect s 44(1)(a) has a “fixed date” construction rather than an “ambulatory” construction and is not affected by any later reassignment of business in the Supreme Court: Forsyth v DCT (2007) 233 ALR 254; [2007] HCA 8; BC200701024 (High Court affirming the NSW Court of Appeal decision Forsyth v DCT (2004) 62 NSWLR 132; 58 ATR 179; [2004] NSWCA 474; BC200409032 . In broad terms, the business assigned to the Common Law Division as at 2 February 1998 included any proceedings that are not specifically required to be heard in the Equity Division of the court or that fall within the kind of business historically assigned to that Division of the court: see SCA s 53(4) . The business of the Common Law Division (and thus that of the District Court, subject to its jurisdictional limit) specifically includes proceedings relating to the various Acts set out in the Supreme Court Rules (prior to the August 2005 amendments): see the former Pt 12 r 4 and Pts 1 and 2 of Schedule H to the Supreme Court rules. The District Court accordingly has jurisdiction in debt recovery actions instituted by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation: Forsyth v DCT (2007) 233 ALR 254; [2007] HCA 8; BC200701024 at [17] , [45] affirming Forsyth v DCT (2004) 62 NSWLR 132; 58 ATR 179; [2004] NSWCA 474; BC200409032 ; Eaton v DCT 2006 ATC 4708; [2006] NSWCA 283; BC200608431 at [20]–[23] , [31] .

Section 44 gives the District Court some jurisdiction to determine whether legal charges are fair and reasonable in circumstances where the bill has not first been considered by a costs assessor: Branson v Tucker [2012] NSWCA 310; BC201207385 at [51] per Campbell JA.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 44.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 4, s 44(1)(d)–(e), s 51(2)(b).

The general jurisdiction of the District Court depends upon the amount the plaintiff actually seeks to recover in the proceedings. The court's jurisdiction is unlimited for proceedings falling within DCA s 44(1)(d)–(e) (motor accident and workplace injury claims and proceedings transferred from the Supreme Court under s 146 of the CPA). Where a set-off is relied upon to bring the claim within the jurisdiction the set-off must be admitted in the pleadings (see the definition of admitted set-off in s 4 ). In identifying the amount claimed it is important to consider the particulars of the claim because, apart from cases where there is an unliquidated claim for general damages, it is the particulars which actually define the amount claimed: Apothecaries Co v Burt (1850) 5 Ex 363; 155 ER 159. If the claim as originally pleaded is not within jurisdiction the court may continue to determine the proceedings if no jurisidictional objection is lodged prior to 3 months before the trial commences: see DCA s 51(2)(b) . Alternatively the court may permit an amendment to bring the proceedings within the jurisdiction: Legon v Count [1945] KB 391; [1945] 1 All ER 710 . In the further alternative, the defendant may be asked to consent to the extended jurisdiction (see [DCA s 51(2)(a)] ). If no such consent is given, and timely objection has been made, then the jurisdictional limit marks the maximum amount which the court can award to the plaintiff for any particular cause of action. It follows that if the amount recoverable by a plaintiff is liable to be reduced, eg, by deductions for contributory negligence or repayments of workers compensation, the deductions must be made from the amount corresponding to the jurisdictional limit notwithstanding that the plaintiff's damages may have been assessed at a sum greater than that figure: Nichols v Patrick Stevedoring Co Pty Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 457.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 44.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 140, s 146.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 146(3), s 44(1)(e).

It is an abuse of process to transfer proceedings to the Supreme Court (pursuant to s 140 of the CPA) after consent to increased jurisdiction has been refused and then seek to have the proceedings immediately remitted back to the District Court (pursuant to s 146 of the CPA) for the purpose of attempting to attract the enlarged jurisdiction provided for in DCA s 44(1)(e) . The purpose of the latter provision is merely to ensure the jurisdictional efficacy of a transfer that has otherwise been properly made and where the prospect of a jurisdictional excess was not anticipated at the time of transfer: see s 146(3) of the CPA and Ge v River Island Clothing Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 935; BC200106501 at [20], [28] .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 44.15] Unliquidated balance of a partnership account

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 44.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 44(1)(c).

heading.title: Unliquidated balance of a partnership account

p.text: An action always lay at common law for the final balance owing on a partnership account provided the balance had been ascertained at the time of the commencement of the action: Moravia v Levy (1786) 2 Term Rep 483; 100 ER 260; Wray v Milestone (1839) 5 M & W 21; 151 ER 10; Henley v Soper (1828) 8 B & C 16; 100 ER 949. Section 44(1)(c) gives the District Court jurisdiction when, although the partnership has ended, the precise value of each partner's share has not been finally quantified. One partner can sue in the District Court for the balance of the partnership account up to the limit of the court's jurisdiction. In such an action the plaintiff would have to prove the total assets and liabilities of the partnership as well as their proportionate share in the net balance: Ex parte Lawry (1868) 7 SCR (NSW) 183; Birkbeck v Crowley (1925) 42 WN (NSW) 86 . In relation to the pleading of such a claim see Wyse v Heggarty (1864) 3 SCR (NSW) 179.

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 44.20] Distributive share under an intestacy or a legacy under a will

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 44.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 44(1)(c).

heading.title: Distributive share under an intestacy or a legacy under a will

p.text: No action lay at common law to recover either a legacy: Deekes v Strutt (1794) 5 Term Rep 693; 101 ER 384; Doe v Guy (1802) 3 East 124; 102 ER 543; or a distributive share in an intestacy; Jones v Tanner (1827) 7 B & C 544; 108 ER 825; Holland v Clark (1841) 1 Y & C Ch Cas 167; 62 ER 831; although an action might lie, at least where the executor had signified their assent, to recover property which was the subject of a specific legacy: Williams v Lee (1745) 3 Atk 223; 26 ER 930; or to recover money held by the executor on behalf of a specific legatee: Gregory v Harman (1828) 1 Moo & P 209; Hart v Minors (1834) 2 Cr & M 700; 149 ER 942. Under the present s 44(1)(c) , the jurisdiction of the District Court is extended to undistributed shares under an intestacy and to legacies. Where the claim is of the latter kind the legacy may be recoverable even though it takes the form of a bequest to the executor in trust. The jurisdiction of the District Court in that event depends upon whether the trust is a “real” trust, that is, whether or not the trustee has any discretionary duties or powers or whether the trustee is a bare trustee: Pears v Wilson (1851) 6 Exch 833; Stanton v Donaldson (1946) 63 WN (NSW) 192 . Thus a bequest in trust to invest money during the minority of an infant, with a power of advancement, is not a legacy for the purposes of the present section: Hewston v Phillips (1856) 11 Exch 695.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 44.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Judiciary Act 1903 s 38, s 39.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 ss 45–51, ss 53–64, ss 69–74, 76, 79, s 86.
(CTH) Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 s 32(1).

This note deals with the law prior to the enactment and proclamation of the cross-vesting legislation which is referred to in note [DCA s 44.30] . Under s 39 of the Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth), state courts are, subject to certain restrictions, invested with federal jurisdiction in all matters in which the High Court has original jurisdiction, or in which original jurisdiction can be conferred upon it, except where the jurisdiction of the High Court is exclusive pursuant to s 38 of the Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth). Problems concerning federal jurisdiction can arise where, aside from the Judiciary Act provisions, exclusive jurisdiction is conferred by federal legislation upon a particular court. The best example of this is s 86 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth), which provides that the Federal Court of Australia has exclusive jurisdiction (except for the High Court) to hear and determine actions, prosecutions and other proceedings under that Act. The difficulty is that the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) includes three different types of provisions: (a) those which create pecuniary penalties (for example, ss 45–51 , 76 ); (b) those which create offences (for example, ss 53–64 , 79 ) and (c) those which provide for certain terms and warranties to be implied in consumer transactions: for example, ss 69–74 . Proceedings in relation to provisions falling within (a) and (b) above are within the Federal Court's exclusive jurisdiction: Stack v Coast Securities (No 9) Pty Ltd (1983) 49 ALR 193; 57 ALJR 731 . Yet, on the other hand, a defence of illegality based on these provisions can be dealt with by a state court (Bestoys Pty Ltd v George Wills & Co Ltd (1981) 36 ALR 366 ; Carlton and United Brewers Ltd v Tooth and Co (1986) 65 ALR 159) as also can a claim in tort alleging a conspiracy to engage in conduct which contravenes them: Galea v Cooper [1982] 2 NSWLR 411. Where proceedings involve a claim for damages for breach of contractual terms implied pursuant to the provisions referred to in (c) they are within the District Court's jurisdiction. The Federal Court has no jurisdiction to entertain such a claim except as part of its “pendent” jurisdiction: Zalai v Col Crawford (Retail) Pty Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 438; (1980) 32 ALR 187 ; disapproving Fletcher v Seddon Atkinson (Aust) Pty Ltd [1979] 1 NSWLR 169; Moorgate Tobacco Ltd v Philip Morris Ltd (1981) 145 CLR 457; 31 ALR 161; Read v Nerey Nominees Pty Ltd [1979] VR 47 ; Arturi v Zupps Motors (1980) 33 ALR 243 . The simple distinction thus drawn between the respective jurisdictions of the Federal Court and the state courts cannot, however, be maintained. This is because of the effect of s 32(1) of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth), which invests the Federal Court with jurisdiction “in respect of matters not otherwise within its jurisdiction that are associated with matters in which the jurisdiction of the Court is invoked”. Provided that a claim to relief is part of the “matter” with which the Federal Court is seized the court may determine that claim even though it arises solely under state law: Philip Morris Inc v Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd (1981) 148 CLR 457; 33 ALR 465 ; Fencott v Muller (1983) 46 ALR 41; 57 ALJR 317 ; Stack v Coast Securities (No 9) Pty Ltd (1983) 49 ALR 193; 57 ALJR 731 ; Adamson v West Perth Football Club Inc (1979) 27 ALR 475 ; Gummow “Pendent Jurisdiction in Australia etc” (1979) 10 Fed Rev 211. Under this principle the Federal Court may acquire jurisdiction to determine claims against persons who would not otherwise be parties if the proceedings were confined to claims arising under federal law — the so-called pendent parties jurisdiction: Kennedy v Australasian Coal and Shale Employees Federation (1983) 50 ALR 735 ; Aristotite v Gladstone Park Shopping Centre Pty Ltd (1984) 55 ALR 387; Stohl Aviation v Electrum Finance Pty Ltd (1984) 5 FCR 187; 56 ALR 716 ; Obacelo Pty Ltd v Taveraft Pty Ltd (1985) 5 FCR 210; 59 ALR 571. Furthermore, once the Federal Court is seized of an associated or pendent claim it may deal with it even if the primary claim based upon federal law is dismissed: Dinyarrak Investments Pty Ltd v Amoco Australia Ltd (1982) 45 ALR 214 .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 44.30] Federal jurisdiction — cross vesting legislation

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 44.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987.
(NSW) Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 Divs 1, 1A.

Substantial changes to the position set out in the preceding note are contained in the cross vesting legislation which has been enacted by the federal and state parliaments. The relevant legislation includes the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1987 (Cth) ; the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 (Cth) and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 (NSW) . Under the first of these enactments various amendments were made to a number of Commonwealth statutes which had the effect of altering the courts upon which jurisdiction was conferred by those statutes. Perhaps the most significant of the changes made, at least in so far as they affected the jurisdiction of the District Court, was to confer jurisdiction under Divs 1 and 1A of Pt V of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) upon “the several courts of the States … within the limits of their several jurisdiction, whether those limits are to locality subject matter or otherwise”. For a consideration of the circumstances in which an action under the Trade Practices Act may be transferred to the court from the Federal Court of Australia see Korn v Paisley Robertson Pty Ltd (1995) 59 FCR 251; BC9502824 . The second and third of the enactments referred to above apply to the various state Supreme Courts and to the Federal Court. In broad terms they provide for reciprocal jurisdiction of all the state Supreme Courts and the Federal Court and will also contain provisions for the transfer of proceedings between those courts. However, they have no effect on the jurisdiction of the District Court: Vale v TMH Haulage Pty Ltd (1993) 31 NSWLR 702 .

From time to time amendments may be made which have the effect of increasing the limit upon the jurisdiction of the court. Where this occurs the effect of the amending legislation upon pending proceedings is a question of statutory interpretation. The answer to that question depends upon construction of the amending provisions as a whole and, in the event that that exercise proves inconclusive, upon categorisation of the amendment as either substantive or merely procedural. The better view is that amendments of this kind are procedural only, with the result that amendments may be made so as to claim the benefit of the increased jurisdictional limit: Ex parte Palmer; Re McCabe (1967) 69 SR (NSW) 140 ; Helensburgh Workers' Club Ltd v Marshall [1984] 2 NSWLR 566 ; not following Parker v Galloway (NSWDC, Staunton DCJ, No 10266/81, 18 April 1983, unreported).

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 44.40] Transfer of matters from Federal Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 44.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 Divs 1, 1A, s 86(2) , s 86(3), Section 86A.

heading.title: Transfer of matters from Federal Court

p.text: Section 86(2) Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) vests the District Court with jurisdiction in matters under Divs 1 and 1A of Pt V. There are some restrictions on the vesting. By s 86(2) the matter must be otherwise within the jurisdiction of the court and by s 86(3) the court is not empowered to grant a remedy that it could not otherwise grant. Section 86A permits the Federal Court to transfer such matters to the District Court. Factors which tend to favour a transfer, include the increased jurisdiction of the court, and the fact that the case raises no issue of principle as to the meaning or application of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth): Nelson v Fernwood Fitness Centre Pty Ltd [1999] FCA 802; BC9903266 . Other factors include the fact that the parties and the witness are resident in country areas of New South Wales. Factors against transfer include where there is also a claim which may be outside the jurisdiction of the District Court such as a particular equity matter: Korn v Paisley Robertson Pty Ltd (1995) 59 FCR 251; BC9502824 . Section 86A fastens upon the remedies sought as at the time the question of transfer arises: Nelson v Fernwood Fitness Centre Pty Ltd [1999] FCA 802; BC9903266 .
[s 45 rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 46] s 46 Ancillary equitable relief: injunctions

p.text: Without affecting the generality of Division 8 , the Court shall, in any action, have power to grant any injunction (whether interlocutory or otherwise) which the Supreme Court might have granted if the action were proceedings in the Supreme Court.
In relation to the power of the Court to grant an injunction under this section—

the Court and the Judges shall, in addition to the powers and authority otherwise conferred on it and them, have all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court and the Judges thereof in the like circumstances;
the appropriate officer of the Court shall, in addition to the duties otherwise imposed on the officer, discharge—
any duty which an officer of the Supreme Court would be required under the practice of the Supreme Court to discharge in the like circumstances; and
any duty imposed on the officer by the rules or by any order of the Court;

the practice and procedure of the Court shall, so far as practicable and subject to this Act and the rules, be the same as the practice and procedure of the Supreme Court applicable in the like circumstances; and

without affecting the generality of the foregoing provisions of this section, the powers, authority and duty conferred by paragraphs (a) and (b) , and the practice and procedure of the Court referred to in paragraph (c) shall, subject to the rules, extend to the enforcement of any order of the Court made in connection with proceedings for the grant of the injunction.
[subs (2) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
Without affecting the generality of any other provision of this Act authorising the making or rules, the rules may make provision for or with respect to—
the procedure to be followed with respect to the granting and enforcing of an injunction under this section; and
any other matter necessary or convenient for giving effect to this section.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 46.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 134, s 44, s 46.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 25.1–25.9.

The injunction power conferred by s 46 is ancillary to the exercise of the court’s basic jurisdiction to hear and dispose of actions of the type specified in s 44 : Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 ; see also Nelson v Fernwood Fitness Centre Pty Ltd [1999] FCA 802; BC9903266 . This ancillary power is complemented by the specific provisions of UCPR rr 25.1–25.9 . The combined effect of these provisions is permit the court, in an action that is otherwise (at least arguably) within its jurisdiction, to grant such injunctive relief (either interlocutory or final) as the Supreme Court could grant in equivalent proceedings before it. It follows that the court may grant ancillary injunctive relief in proceedings involving a common law claim: Ciccarelli v Cavasinni Developments [2004] NSWSC 788; BC200405706 ; Overmyer Industrial Brokers Pty Ltd v Campbells Cash & Carry Pty Ltd (2004) Aust Contract Reports ¶90-181; [2003] NSWCA 305; BC200306233 at [58] , [63] per Young CJ in Eq (precluding reliance on the Statute of Frauds as a formal defence). Apart from this ancillary jurisdiction the courts other substantive power to grant injunctive relief is contained in s 134 and is subject to the monetary limits set out in that section.

There is no power to order non parties to pay moneys to discharge a judgment debt: Lin v Borrowdale [2011] NSWCA 65; BC201101475 at [50]–[52] per Whealy JA, at [1]–[2] Macfarlan and Young JJA agreeing (money held by judgment debtor’s former solicitor).

A direction to a solicitor of a former client who is holding money held on behalf of the client in a trust account to pay the money to solicitors for the opposing party, the judgment creditor, in partial satisfaction of the judgment, is beyond the power authorised by DCA s 46 . Such an order is a form of enforcement order itself. It is neither ancillary to the hearing and disposal of a s 44 action, nor is it an injunction to preserve assets pending execution upon the judgment in aid of enforcement: Lin v Borrowdale [2011] NSWCA 65; BC201101475 at [50]–[52] per Whealy JA, Macfarlan and Young JJA at [1]–[2] agreeing. Further, it is inappropriate to make any such order where the funds are not being held subject to any direction of the court, the solicitor has not consented to the direction, and where no consideration is given as to whether he should be given notice of the proposed direction, so that he could address it: Lin v Borrowdale, aboveat [44]–[45] per Whealy JA, Macfarlan and Young JJA at [1]–[2] agreeing.

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 46.10] Mareva/ asset preservation orders — jurisdiction and effect

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 46.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 25.10–25.17, r 25.2(1)(c).

heading.title: Mareva/ asset preservation orders — jurisdiction and effect

p.text: This section has been held to permit the District Court to grant Mareva asset preservation orders: Harpay Pty Ltd v Grech (NSWDC, Gee DCJ, 14 December 1982, unreported); M & HJ Webb Pty Ltd v Doherty (NSWSC, Young J, 29 April 1994, unreported, BC9402519); Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . UCPR r 25.2(1)(c) confers a specific power to grant both Mareva and Anton Piller orders. The principles relating to the grant of such orders are discussed in the notes to UCPR rr 25.10–25.17 .

The District Court has an implied power to make a freezing or restraining order in respect of the assets of a third party where there is evidence that a judgment debtor has taken steps to alienate property to a third party, when that property would otherwise have been available for execution at the instance of the judgment creditor. Any such order can only be made in accordance with the principles in Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 : Tagget v Sexton [2009] NSWCA 91; BC200903213 at [64] per Beazley JA (Young JA agreeing).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 47] s 47 Cause of action or defendant outside the State

leg:heading.title: Cause of action or defendant outside the State

p.text: If a defendant has been duly served with the document commencing an action:
the Court has jurisdiction in accordance with this Act to hear and dispose of the action, and
a registrar has and may exercise:
if the action involves proceedings to which the Civil Procedure Act 2005 applies, the functions conferred on the registrar pursuant to section 12 or 13 of that Act, or
in any other case, the functions prescribed by the civil procedure rules,
regardless of whether the cause of action to which the action relates arose wholly or partly outside New South Wales.
[subs (1) subst Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]
For the purposes of subsection (1) , it is immaterial whether the defendant was within or outside New South Wales:
at the time the cause of action arose, or
at the time of service of the document commencing the action.

For the purposes of this section, a defendant is duly served with a document commencing an action if the defendant is served with the document by or under this Act or in accordance with the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 of the Commonwealth.
In this section, defendant includes, if there are two or more defendants, any one of those defendants.
[s 47 subst Act 172 of 1998 Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 47.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.3.

Under the general law a court's jurisdiction in personam depended upon service of its originating process (John Russell & Co Ltd v Cayzer, Irvine & Co Ltd [1916] 2 AC 298 at 302; Cotter v Workman (1972) 20 FLR 318 ; Coppin v Tobler Bros Canberra Marine Centre Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 183 ) and service could only be effected upon those who were actually present within the jurisdiction (Berkley v Thompson (1884) 10 App Cas 45 at 49) or perhaps those who voluntarily submitted to the court's jurisdiction or contracted so to do: Emmanuel v Simon [1908] 1 KB 302 at 308; Vogel v Kohnstramm [1973] QB 133 . There was no power to permit service of process outside the jurisdiction (Re Anglo-African Steamship Co (1886) 32 Ch 348 at 350; Lenders v Anderson (1883) 12 QBD 50 ; Trower & Sons Ltd v Ripstein [1944] AC 254 ; Laurie v Carroll (1958) 98 CLR 310; 32 ALJR 7 ) and in the absence of contrary legislative provision a judgment in a personal action where the originating process had been served outside the jurisdiction was not recognised outside the jurisdiction: Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v Rajah of Faridkote [1894] AC 670 at 684 ; City Finance Co Ltd v Matthew Harvey & Co Ltd (1915) 21 CLR 55 at 60 . The present section does not itself grant power to permit service of the court's process outside New South Wales. However, service may be effected pursuant to the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 . UCPR r 10.3 which permits service of documents in Australia only applies in the Supreme Court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 48] s 48 Miscellaneous limitations on jurisdiction

p.text: An action in which the amount claimed does not exceed $4,000 and which could have been commenced in the Local Court shall not be commenced in the District Court except with the leave of the District Court, which leave may be given on terms.
[subs (1) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Schs 3, 7 ; Act 282 of 1987 s 2 and Sch 1 ; Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
Subject to subsection (3) , the Court shall not have jurisdiction in an action in which title to land the value of which is more than the Court's jurisdictional limit is in question.
[subs (2) am Act 1 of 1975 s 3 ; Act 41 of 1982 s 5 and Sch 1 ; Act 12 of 1991 s 3 and Sch 2(2) ; Act 58 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]

If the title to land the value of which is more than the Court's jurisdictional limit incidentally comes in question in an action, the Court shall have power to decide the claim which it is the immediate object of the action to enforce, but the judgment of the Court shall not be evidence of title between the parties on their privies in other proceedings in the Court or in any proceedings in any other court.
[subs (3) am Act 1 of 1975 s 3 ; Act 41 of 1982 s 5 and Sch 1 ; Act 12 of 1991 s 3 and Sch 2(2) ; Act 58 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]
Without affecting Division 8 , the Court shall not have jurisdiction in actions for possession of land by virtue of this Part.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 48.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 4, s 44, s 48(2).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 3.

The court’s “jurisdictional limit” is defined in s 4 DCA and s 3 CPA (currently $750,000). A provision such as s 48(2) was contained in most of the legislative predecessors of the present Act. However, unlike them the monetary limit upon the value of land referred to in the subsection is the same as the ordinary jurisdictional limit provided for in s 44 . Previously, the District Court's jurisdiction where title to land was in question was set at a monetary limit below that which applied to ordinary actions at law.

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 48.10] When title is in issue

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 48.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 48(2).

Before s 48(2) will operate to exclude the District Court's jurisdiction it must be shown that there is a bona fide issue as to the title to land: Ex parte McEvoy (1868) 8 SCR (NSW) 16; Irwin v Burton (1934) 51 WN (NSW) 137 ; Ex parte Gane (1887) 3 WN (NSW) 137. Title is not put in issue if the plaintiff is merely put to proof of his title (British Insulated Wire Co Ltd v Prescot Urban District Council [1895] 2 QB 538) or if the right claimed against the land is not one recognised by law: Lloyd v Jones (1848) 6 CB 81; 136 ER 1182. A claim for damages for trespass to land puts in question the plaintiff's title: Timothy v Farmer (1849) 7 CB 814; 137 ER 323; Ex parte Farelly (1868) 7 SCR (NSW) 227; Ex parte Charlton (1869) 8 SCR (NSW) 158. However, a claim for damages to chattels standing upon the land may not do so: Thompson v Rix (1886) 2 WN (NSW) 87; De Faur v Nicholls (1876) 18 SCR (NSW) 382. A claim to a right of way (Ex parte M'Gregor (1881) 2 LR (NSW) 45) or a lease (Irwin v Burton (1934) 51 WN (NSW) 137 ) necessarily raises a question as to the title to the land. In an action to recover rates a dispute as to the municipality within which the land lies does not raise a question about the title to land: Camperdown Borough v Prenderghast (1888) 5 WN (NSW) 30. On the other hand, such a question is raised if the defendant disputes that he is the owner of the land: Granville Borough v Armstrong (1897) 18 LR (NSW) 426; 14 WN (NSW) 63.
